sentences.sentence: “I was so pleased at my own good luck.
Well, I thought about it all day, and by evening I was depressed( 沮丧的 ) again.
I had quite persuaded myself that the whole affair must be some trick,
though what its purpose might be I could not imagine.
It seemed unbelievable that anyone would make such a will,
or that they would pay such a sum( 一笔钱 ) for doing anything so simple as copying out the Encyclopedia Britannica( 大英百科全书 ).
However, in the morning I determined to try it anyhow, so I bought a penny bottle of ink,
and with a pen and seven large sheets of paper I started off for Pope’s Court.
Well, to my surprise and delight, everything was as right as possible.
The table was set out ready for me,
and Mr( 先生 ). Duncan Ross was there to see that I got properly to work.
He started me off with the letter A, and then he left me;
but he would drop in( 过来 ) from time to time( 偶尔，有时 ) to see that all was right with me.
At two o’clock he said goodbye, complimented( 称赞 ) me upon the amount that I had written,
and locked the door of the office after me.
This went on day after day, Mr( 先生 ). Holmes,
and on Saturday the manager came in and gave me four golden one-pound coins for my week’s work.
It was the same next week, and the week after that.
Every morning I was there at ten, and every afternoon I left at two.
Mr( 先生 ). Duncan Ross took to coming in only once a day,
and then, after a time, he did not come in at all.
Still, of course, I never dared to leave the room for an instant,
for I was not sure when he might come,
and the job was such a good one, and suited me so well, that I would not risk losing it.
Eight weeks passed away like this,
and I had written about Abbots and Archery and Armour and Architecture and Attica,
and hoped with hard work that I might get on to the B’s before very long.
It cost me something in paper, and I had nearly filled a shelf with my writings.
And then suddenly the whole business came to an end.”
“To an end?”
“Yes, sir. This morning, I went to my work as usual at ten o’clock,
but the door was shut and locked, with a little square of cardboard( 硬纸板 ) fastened to it with a nail.
Here it is, you can read it for yourself.”
He held up( 举起 ) a piece of white cardboard( 硬纸板 ) about the size of a sheet of note-paper. It said:
THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE IS DISSOLVED( 解散 ). October 9, 1890.
Sherlock Holmes and I looked at this short announcement and the sad face behind it,
until the funny side of the affair so completely overwhelmed( 压倒 ) every other consideration that we both burst out into laughter.
“I cannot see that there is anything very funny,” cried our client( 客户，委托人 ), his face turning almost as red as his hair.
“If you can do nothing better than laugh at me, I can go elsewhere.”
“No, no,” cried Holmes, pushing him back into the chair from which he had half risen.
“I really wouldn’t miss your case for the world( 决不，无论如何也不 ).
It is most refreshingly unusual.
But there is, if you will excuse my saying so, something just a little funny about it.
What did you do when you found the card upon the door?”
“At first I did not know what to do.
Then I asked at the other offices in the building, but none of them seemed to know anything about it.
Finally, I went to the landlord, who is an accountant living on the ground floor,
and I asked him if he could tell me what had become of( 情况如何 ) the Red-headed League.
He said that he had never heard of any such organization.
Then I asked him who Mr( 先生 ). Duncan Ross was.
He answered that he did not recognize the name.
‘Well,’ said I, ‘the gentleman at No. 4.’
‘What, the red-headed man?’
‘Yes.’
‘Oh,’ said he, ‘his name is William Morris.
He is a lawyer, and was using the room temporarily until his new offices were ready.
He moved out yesterday.’
‘Where could I find him?’
‘Oh, at his new offices. He did tell me the address. Yes, 17 King Edward Street, near St. Paul’s.’
I started off, Mr( 先生 ). Holmes, but when I got to that address it was a small factory making artificial knee-caps( 膝盖骨 ),
and no one in it had ever heard of either Mr( 先生 ). William Morris or Mr( 先生 ). Duncan Ross.”
“And what did you do then?” asked Holmes.
“I went home to Saxe-Coburg Square, and I took the advice of my assistant.
But he could not help me in any way.
He could only say that if I waited I should hear by post.
But that was not quite good enough, Mr( 先生 ). Holmes.
I did not wish to lose such a place without a struggle,
so, as I had heard that you were good enough to give advice to poor people who were in need of it, I came right away to you.”
“And you did very wisely,” said Holmes.
“Your case is a very remarkable one, and I shall be happy to look into it.
From what you have told me I think it is possible that more important issues depend on( 取决于 ) it than are obvious at first sight.”
“Important enough!” said Mr( 先生 ). Jabez Wilson. “I have lost four pounds a week.”
“I do not see that you have any personal reason to complain against this extraordinary league.
On the contrary, you are, as I understand, richer by some 30 pounds,
to say nothing of( 更不用说 ) the detailed knowledge which you have gained on every subject which begins the letter A.
You have lost nothing.”
“No, sir. But I want to find out about them, and who they are, and what their object was in playing this joke—if it was a joke—upon me.
It was a pretty expensive joke for them, for it cost them thirty-two pounds.”
“We shall try to clear up these points for you.
And, first, one or two questions, Mr( 先生 ). Wilson.
This assistant of yours who first called your attention to the advertisement—how long had he been with you?”
“About a month then.”
“How did he come?”
“In answer to an advertisement.”
“Was he the only applicant?”
“No, I had a dozen.”
“Why did you pick him?”
“Because he was intelligent and would work cheap.”
“At half-wages, in fact.”
“Yes.”
“What is he like, this Vincent Spaulding?”
“Small, solidly built, very quick in his movements, no hair on his face, though he’s at least thirty.
Has a white splash( 色块，光斑 ) of acid upon his forehead.”
Holmes sat up in his chair in considerable excitement.
“I thought as much,” said he. “Have you ever noticed that his ears are pierced( 刺穿 ) for earrings?”
“Yes, sir. He told me that a gypsy( 吉普赛人 ) had done it for him when he was a boy.”
“Hum( 唔，语气词 )!” said Holmes, sitting back in deep thought.
“He is still with you?”
“Oh, yes, sir; I have only just left him.”
“And has your business been well cared for in your absence?”
“Nothing to complain of, sir. There’s never very much to do in the mornings.”
“That will do, Mr( 先生 ). Wilson.
I shall be happy to give you an opinion upon the subject in a day or two.
Today is Saturday, and I hope that by Monday we may have found the answer.”

article_info.previous: Mr. Wilson从助手Vincent Spaulding处得知有一个红发会的组织为红头发的人提供轻松且薪水高的工作。Mr. Wilson通过面试得到了这份工作，工作内容为抄写百科全书，且工作期间不得以任何理由离开办公室。
article_info.share_words: Sherlock Holmes and I looked at this short announcement and the sad face behind it, until the funny side of the affair so completely overwhelmed every other consideration that we both burst out into laughter.

question.cn: 面试过后Mr. Wilson做了什么？
question.en: What did Mr. Wilson do after the interview?

options.cn: 他觉得这份工作是个恶作剧所以没有去工作。
options.en: He thought the job was a trick so he did not go to work.

options.cn: 他觉得红发会这个组织太奇怪了所以没有去工作。
options.en: He thought the Red-Headed League was very strange so he did not go to work.

options.cn: 他决定试一下，于是去工作了。
options.en: He determined to have a try and went to work.

analysis: 文中提到“However, in the morning I determined to try it anyhow, so I bought a penny bottle of ink, and with a pen and seven large sheets of paper I started off for Pope’s Court.”所以选C。

question.cn: 我们能从门上钉的白卡片纸知道什么？
question.en: What could we know from the white cardboard fastened to the door?

options.en: The Red-Headed League came into being.
The Red-Headed League moved their office.

analysis: 文中提到“It said: THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE IS DISSOLVED. October 9, 1890.”所以选B。

question.cn: 看到门上的卡片后，Mr. Wilson做了什么？
question.en: What did Mr. Wilson do after he found the card upon the door?

options.cn: 他回了家，其他的什么都没做。
options.en: He went back home and did nothing else.

options.cn: 他联系了警察寻求帮助。
options.en: He asked the police for help.

options.cn: 他询问了其他办公室的人和房东。
options.en: He asked the people at other offices and the landlord about it.

analysis: 文中Mr. Wilson说：“Then I asked at the other offices in the building. . . Finally, I went to the landlord. . . ”所以选C。

question.cn: Mr. Wilson为什么想要找出整件事情背后的缘由？
question.en: Why did Mr. Wilson want to find out the reason behind the whole thing?

options.cn: 因为他不想失去这份工作带来的每周四磅的收入。
options.en: Because he did not want to lose every week’s four pounds brought by this job.

options.cn: 因为他是一个好奇心很重的人。
options.en: Because he was a curious person.

options.cn: 因为他觉得自己被戏弄了所以很生气。
options.en: Because he was angry that somebody tricked him.

analysis: 文中提到“I did not wish to lose such a place without a struggle. . . I have lost four pounds a week.”所以选A。

question.cn: Mr. Wilson为什么选择Vincent Spaulding做助手？
question.en: Why did Mr. Wilson choose Vincent Spaulding as his assistant?

options.cn: 因为他是唯一的申请者。
options.en: Because he was the only applicant.

options.cn: 因为他聪明而且要求的工资低。
options.en: Because he was intelligent and would work cheap.

options.cn: 因为他之前做过类似的工作。
options.en: Because he had done similar work before.

analysis: 文中提到“‘Was he the only applicant?’ ‘No, I had a dozen.’ ‘Why did you pick him?’ ‘Because he was intelligent and would work cheap.’”所以选B。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第48天
